PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN, JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: CBA to pay AUD 700mln to resolve AUSTRAC proceedings; Trump declares US-North Korea summit is back on
content:
AUSTRALIA

Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA AT)
- Co. resolves anti-money laundering/counter-terrorist finance proceedings with AUSTRAC in which it will pay a civil penalty of AUD 700mln. (Newswires)

CYBG (CYBG AT)
- Co. submitted a revised proposal for Virgin Money. (Newswires)

Kogan.com (KGN AT)
- Co. inks supply and logistic deals what will permit it to enter the domestic whitegoods and built-in kitchen appliance sector. (Newswires)

Telstra (TLS AT)
- Co. is said to have halted all new investments and are said to currently be under ‘lockdown’. (Newswires)

Topbetta Holdings (TBH AT)
- Co. sees negative operating cash flows for the short-term. (Newswires)

Vicinity Centres (VCX AT)
- Co. is planning to offload as much as AUD 1.0bln of sub-regional and neighbour hood shopping centres. (Newswires)

Westpac (WBC AT)
- Co. is said to be mulling closing Ascalon capital management unit. (Newswires)

Energy
- WTI crude fell 2% to below USD 66.00/bbl on Friday. (Newswires)

JAPAN

Mazda (7261 JT)
- Co. reported May US sales rose 15.1% Y/Y to 30.0k units. (Newswires)

SBI Holdings (8473 JT)
- Co. is expected to start operations for cryptocurrency exchange today. (Newswires)

SoftBank (9984 JT)
- Co. has lined up 3 potential successors to CEO Masayoshi Son. (Nikkei)

Subaru (7270 JT)
- Co. reported May North America sales rose 7.2% Y/Y to 60.1k units. (Newswires)

SOUTH KOREA

CJ E&M Corp. (0130960 KS)
- Co. is said to be planning a US film production and distribution. (Newswires)

Daelim Industrial (000210 KS)
- Co. cancelled a USD 2.08bln contract from Iran due to US sanctions. (Newswires)

Hyosung (004800 KS)
- Co. officially began a holding group and 4 affiliate entities to improve transparency in management and corporate governance. (Newswires)

Hyundai Motor (005380 KS)
- Co. May sales rose 5.7% Y/Y to 387.0k unit. (Newswires)
- Co. May US sales rose 10% Y/Y to 66.1k units.

Hyundai Rotem (064350 KS)
- Co. receives Taiwan order valued at KRW 909.8bln. (Newswires)

Kia Motors (000270 KS)
- Co. May vehicle sales rose 9% Y/Y to 247.2k units. (Newswires)
- Co. America unit sales rose 1.6% Y/Y to 59.5k units.

subject: China Q2 growth is expected at between 6.7%-6.8%, according to China Daily Commentary

ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights Include Australian Retail Sales and Japanese Monetary Base; New Zealand is shut for holiday
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS:
content:
TRADE

US Commerce Secretary Ross travelled to Beijing the past weekend for the 3rd round of trade talks with China which ended without a deal. However, there were comments by Ross that meetings were friendly and frank, while China commented that they have made concrete progress and that any action by US to impose punitive tariffs would derail the negotiations. (Newswires)

US President Trump's administration reportedly might claim a USD 1.7bln penalty against ZTE, as two sides are discussing removing the commerce ban, according to sources. (Newswires)

US President Trump said on Friday that he would be open to having separate trade deals with Canada and Mexico. (Newswires)

White House Economic Advisor Kudlow stated that Canadian PM Trudeau’s response to the US tariffs on steel and aluminium was an overreaction, while he added the tariffs may last a while or not which is subject to negotiations and that he views the issue as more of a family quarrel. (Newswires)

Canada launched WTO and NAFTA cases on US metal tariffs. (Newswires)
 

UK/EU

ECB's Weidmann (Hawk) said direct impact on US tariffs on the EU economy are limited but noted that trade wars are a large risk for economic development. (Newswires)

S&P affirmed Ireland at 'A+/A-1'; outlook stable. (Newswires)

Fitch Affirmed Belgium at 'AA-'; Outlook Stable and affirmed Portugal at 'BBB'; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)


COMMODITIES

US Baker Hughes Total Rig Count (25 May) 1060 (Prev. 1059). (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump said the meeting with North Korean Leader Kim Jong Un is back on which is to take place in Singapore on June 12th and noted the North Koreans want to denuclearise, while there were also reports that US President trump does not want to use the term ‘Maximum pressure’ as they are getting along with North Korea. (Newswires)
 

US

Fed’s Williams (Voter, Hawkish) said Fed should continue with gradual hikes over the upcoming two years and that he expects US rates to be neutral after three more hikes. Furthermore, Williams also stated the Fed should not necessarily pause once it reaches neutral if economy remains firm. (Newswires)

US Non-Farm Payrolls (May) 223k vs. Exp. 188k (Prev. 164k, Rev. 159k). (Newswires)
US Unemployment Rate (May) 3.8% vs. Exp. 3.9% (Prev. 3.9%)
US Average Earnings YY (May) 2.7% vs. Exp. 2.7% (Prev. 2.6%)
US ISM Manufacturing PMI (May) 58.7 vs. Exp. 58.2 (Prev. 57.3)
US Markit Manufacturing PMI Final (May) 56.4 (Prev. 56.6)
 

MARKET RECAP

US Equity futures benefitted from a risk-on tone on Friday, as political tensions eased in Europe. The constructive risk environment saw the S&P 500 Emini grinding higher through the course of the session, despite a slight dip following the US jobs report; however, downticks were fleeting and the futures resumed ricking higher through the course of the session, breaking the key 2730 level but finding resistance just shy of 2740 where selling was observed. Utilities expressed its defensive nature again due to the risk-on tone, and it closed heavily in the red where it was totting-up losses around 2%; the outperformers were led by tech, carrying on its recent gains. Utility names and energy names seemed to be weighing on Friday, again due to the defensive nature, while lower oil prices were also cited. SPX +1.07% at 2734 , NDX +1.67% at 7084, DJI +0.89% at 24633.

The Treasury complex was under pressure for most of Friday, along with decent volume, as political tensions in Europe eased, a decent NFP report, and news that the summit with North Korea is back on. However, although yields were higher across the curve by between 6-8bps, major curves continued to narrow, with 2s30s over 2bps narrower, and 5s30s flatter by around the same margin; 2s5s was relatively unchanged. US 10yr T-Notes futures (Sep 2018) settled 19 ticks lower at 119-27.
